trial_identification.studytitle: A Phase II Study of Abatacept Versus Placebo to Assess the Prevention of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) in Adult Patients With Undifferentiated Arthritis Who Are at High Risk for the Development of RA
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A Phase II Study of Abatacept Versus Placebo to Assess the Prevention of Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) in Adult Patients With Undifferentiated Arthritis Who Are at High Risk for the Development of RA

interventions.interventions: Drug: Abatacept for the first 6 months, then 18 months oberservation. Study Design: Educational/Counseling/Training, Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo Control, Parallel Assignment, Safety/Efficacy Study
interventions.comparator: Drug: Placebo for the first 6 months, then 18 months oberservation.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Proportion of subjects wih a diagnosis of Rheumatoid Arthritis by ARA criteria

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Proportion of subjects with a diagnosis of RA by 1987 ARA criteria.
The proportion of subjects with persistent symptomatic clinical synovitis.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Diagnosis of undifferentiated arthritis Clinical synovitis of two or more joints At least one but not more than three of the criteria for diagnosis of RA (1987). No prior disease modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs)/biologics. Duration of disease must be 18 months or less. Positive for antibodies against cyclic citrullinated peptides.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Women of child bearing potential who are unwilling or unable to use an acceptable method to avoid pregnancy. Men unwilling to use an adequate method of contraception. Active vasculitis of a major organ system. Severe or recurrent bacterial infection. History of cancer in the last five years except certain skin cancers. Herpes zoster that resolved less than 2 months prior to enrollment.

trial_design.concealment: Treatment allocated through central randomisation system by phone and fax
trial_design.sequence: Computer generated to randomly allocate treatment, Randomisation will be stratified into two groups based on the presence or absence of erosions.

contact.name: Associate Professor Geoff Littlejohn
